revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Jenny Slate | image = Jenny Slate Obvious Child Premiere 2014 (cropped).jpg | caption = Slate at the 2014 ''[[Obvious Child]]'' premiere at the ArcLight Hollywood theater | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|3|25}} | birth_place = [[Milton, Massachusetts]], U.S. | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | education = [[Milton Academy]] | alma_mater = [[Columbia University]] | occupation = Stand-up comedian, actress, author | years_active = 2005–present | spouse = {{marriage|Dean Fleischer-Camp
|2012|2016|reason=separated}}{{cite news|last1=King|first1=Brittany|title=Jenny Slate and Husband Dean Fleischer-Camp Split|url=http://www.people.com/article/jenny-slate-husband-dean-fleischer-camp-split|accessdate=August 1, 2016|publisher=People|date=May 4, 2016}} | birthname = Jenny Sarah Slate }} '''Jenny Sarah Slate''' (born March 25, 1982) is an American stand-up comedian, actress and author, best known for her role as Mona Lisa Saperstein on ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' as well as being the co-creator of the ''[[Marcel the Shell with Shoes On]]'' short films and children's book series. She was a cast member on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' for the [[Saturday Night Live (season 35)|2009/10 season]] and appeared in shows such as ''[[House of Lies]]'', ''[[Married (TV series)|Married]]'', ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'', [[Hello Ladies|''Hello'' ''Ladies'']], ''[[Kroll Show]]'', ''[[Bored to Death]]'', and ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'', as well as movies like ''[[Zootopia]]'', ''[[The Secret Life of Pets]]'', and ''[[Despicable Me 3]]''. Slate played the lead role in the 2014 film ''[[Obvious Child]]'', and in 2016 she was in ''[[Brain on Fire (film)|Brain on Fire]]''. ==Early life== Slate was born on March 25, 1982 in [[Milton, Massachusetts]],{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/jenny-slate/photos/298545/ | title=Jenny Slate| publisher=[[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]]| accessdate=May 11, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:KK7N-VJW |title= Jenny Sarah Slate| publisher=FamilySearch.org|accessdate=May 11, 2016}} to Ron Slate (born 1950),{{cite web|url=http://www.ronslate.com/about_ron_slate|title=About Ron Slate - On the Seawall: A Literary Website by Ron Slate (GD)|website=www.ronslate.com}} a businessman and poet who worked as vice president of global communications for the [[Dell EMC|EMC Corporation]] and later as CEO of a biotech startup,{{Cite web|url=http://www.ronslate.com/about_ron_slate|title=About Ron Slate {{!}} On the Seawall: A Literary Website by Ron Slate (GD)|website=www.ronslate.com|language=en|access-date=July 25, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.bostonmagazine.com/boston_daily/2009/02/27/questions-for-jenny-slate |title=Questions For: Jenny Slate |date=February 27, 2009 |work=Boston Daily |accessdate=August 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113152818/http://blogs.bostonmagazine.com/boston_daily/2009/02/27/questions-for-jenny-slate |archivedate=November 13, 2009 }}Slate, Ron (April 7, 2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=DJM1pnyJC2MC&pg=PT64&dq=%22The+Incentive+of+the+Maggot%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gZS_U-W3GYSOyASmx4LQAw&ved=0CBMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Jenny&f=false ''The Incentive of the Maggot'']. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. p. v. Archived at [[Google Books]]. Retrieved September 10, 2014. and Nancy ([[née]] Gilson), a [[Ceramic art|ceramicist]].{{Cite news|url=http://jewishjournal.com/culture/arts/130066/|title=Comedian Jenny Slate in Obvious Child|date=June 30, 2014|work=Jewish Journal|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} She is the middle child of three, with an older sister named Abigail and younger sister named Stacey.{{Cite news|url=http://www.miltontimes.com/DOTnet-frontJUMPS-JennySlate.html |title=Jenny Slate Joins the Cast of 'Saturday Night Live' |last=Kurtz Ferrari |first=Kathy |date=September 24, 2009 |work=Milton Times |accessdate=August 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714094755/http://www.miltontimes.com/DOTnet-frontJUMPS-JennySlate.html |archivedate=July 14, 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|last1=Yuan|first1=Jada|title=The Year of Living Publicly|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/03/jenny-slate-gifted-chris-evans-breakup.html?mid=twitter_vulture|publisher=Vulture.com|accessdate=March 21, 2017|date=March 21, 2017}} She was raised in a [[Jewish]] family.{{Cite news|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/jenny-slate-2612392|title=Jenny Slate|last=Molyneaux|first=Libby|date=December 6, 2012|work=[[LA Weekly]]|accessdate=June 23, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/227356/drawing-inspiration-from-jenny-slates-game-changing-hair|title=Jewish Comedian Jenny Slate on Learning to Love Her Curly Hair|accessdate=June 23, 2018|date=March 13, 2017|last=Cooper|first=Miranda|work=[[Tablet (magazine)|Tablet Magazine]]}} One of her grandmothers was born in [[Cuba]], to a family from Russia and Turkey, and was raised in France.{{cite web|url=http://bullettmedia.com/article/jenny-slate-career-making-film-obvious-child/ |title=Jenny Slate On Her Career-Making Film 'Obvious Child' |work=bullettmedia.com |accessdate=May 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151023215249/http://bullettmedia.com/article/jenny-slate-career-making-film-obvious-child/ |archivedate=October 23, 2015 |df= }} After graduating from [[Milton Academy]] as the [[valedictorian]], Slate attended [[Columbia University]] as a literature major, where she helped form the [[Improvisational theatre|improv]] group Fruit Paunch, starred in the Varsity Show{{Cite news|url=http://www.columbiaspectator.com/2002/05/03/varsity-show-reach-exceeds-its-grasp|title=Varsity Show Reach Exceeds Its Grasp|last=Fitzner|first=Ana|date=May 3, 2002|work=Columbia Spectator|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} and met Gabe Liedman, who would become her comedy partner.{{Cite news|url=http://intothegloss.com/2014/06/jenny-slate-quote/|title=Jenny Slate|date=June 2014|work=Into the Gloss|accessdate=July 2, 2014}} Slate graduated from Columbia in 2004. ==Career== Alongside Gabe Liedman, Slate was half of the comedy duo Gabe & Jenny.{{Cite news|url=http://gothamist.com/2009/06/10/gabe_liedman_and_jenny_slate_comedi.php|title=Gabe Liedman and Jenny Slate, Comedians|last=Parker|first=Billy|date=June 10, 2009|work=Gothamist|accessdate=August 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304101223/http://gothamist.com/2009/06/10/gabe_liedman_and_jenny_slate_comedi.php|archivedate=March 4, 2010|df=mdy-all}} Their live stand-up shows with Max Silvestri titled ''Big Terrific'' were named best new variety show of 2008 by ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]] [[New York City|New York]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/comedy/69876/comedy-the-best-and-worst-of-2008|title=Comedy: The best (and worst) of 2008|last=Borden|first=Jane|date=December 2008|work=Time Out New York|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} In 2015, Slate, Liedman, and Silvestri announced that the show would be ending due to their busy schedules,{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/04/slate-liedman-and-silvestri-on-big-terrific.html|title=Jenny Slate, Gabe Liedman, and Max Silvestri on the End of Their Weekly Comedy Show, Big Terrific|date=April 22, 2015|publisher=}} though they continue to perform together when possible. Slate first met Liedman in 2000 while attending [[Columbia University]].{{Cite news|url=http://gothamist.com/2007/05/04/gabe_liedman_an.php|title=Gabe Liedman and Jenny Slate, A Night with Gabe and Jenny|last=Karakh|first=Ben|date=May 4, 2007|work=Gothamist|accessdate=August 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412000839/http://gothamist.com/2007/05/04/gabe_liedman_an.php|archivedate=April 12, 2010|df=mdy-all}} They describe their relationship as a "nonsexual romance" and Slate says, "I like to think of us as kind of like [[Elaine Benes]] and [[George Costanza]], but we like each other." Throughout 2008 and 2009, Slate regularly performed her one-woman show titled ''Jenny Slate: Dead Millionaire'' at the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre]] (UCBT) in [[New York City]].{{Cite web|url=http://newyork.ucbtheatre.com/performers/3982 |title=Jenny Slate |work=Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre |accessdate=August 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830030251/http://newyork.ucbtheatre.com/performers/3982 |archivedate=August 30, 2010 |df= }} [[File:Jenny Slate and Gabe Liedman in 2007.jpg|thumb|left|Slate with comedy partner Gabe Liedman in 2007]] Slate was a regular commentator on many [[VH1]] "talking head" commentary programs. In early 2009, she had made several appearances on the ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' recurring sketch "7th Floor West", where she played an [[NBC page]] also named Jenny, who was later promoted to [[Jimmy Fallon|Fallon]]'s assistant. She also had a recurring role in ''[[Bored to Death]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2009/09/vulture_interviews_new_saturda.html|title=Vulture Interviews New ''Saturday Night Live'' Cast Member Jenny Slate|date=September 11, 2009|work=Vulture|publisher=New York Magazine|accessdate=August 18, 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2009/11/09/bored-to-death-jenny-slate-hbo/|title='Bored to Death:' Jenny Slate, please come back|last=Barrett|first=Annie|date=November 9, 2009|work=PopWatch|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} Slate has made guest appearances on television programs, such as ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'', ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'', ''[[The Whitest Kids U' Know]]'', ''[[Important Things with Demetri Martin]]'' and ''[[Raising Hope]]''. Slate joined the cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' for one season from 2009 to 2010.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/bios/jenny-slate.shtml |title=Jenny Slate |accessdate=September 28, 2009|publisher=''[[Saturday Night Live]]''}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/SNL-New-Cast-1009401.aspx|title=Saturday Night Live Adds Two New Cast Members|last=Bryant|first=Adam|date=September 9, 2009|publisher=tvguide.com}} In her first episode, she accidentally said "fucking" during her debut sketch "Biker Chick Chat", which was heard on the live broadcast, but removed from reruns.Schwindt, Oriana (September 15, 2014). "What's Worth Watching". ''[[TV Guide]]''. p. 79{{Cite news|url=http://www.pbpulse.com/tv/saturday-night-live/2009/09/28/saturday-night-live-starts-season-with-f-bomb/#more-32270|title='Saturday Night Live' starts season with F-bomb|date=September 28, 2009|work=Associated Press|accessdate=August 18, 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/12/13/jenny-slate-drops-the-f-bomb-on-snl/|title=TV Moment of 2009: Jenny Slate Drops the F-Bomb on 'SNL'|last=Hollowell|first=Jenny|date=December 13, 2009|work=TV Squad|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} During her brief time on the series, she impersonated celebrities such as [[Hoda Kotb]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Kristen Stewart]], [[Ashley Olsen]], and [[Olympia Snowe]] and became known for Tina-Tina Cheneuse, an infomercial pitchwoman who advertises personalized doorbells, car horns, and alarm clocks.{{cite web|last=Anne|first=Sarah|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/celebritology/2010/09/jenny_slate_leaves_saturday_ni.html|title=Celebritology 2.0 – Jenny Slate leaves 'Saturday Night Live', and we ask, what went wrong?|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=September 8, 2010}} Slate's contract was not renewed for another season.{{cite web|last=Itzkoff|first=Dave|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/07/saturday-night-live-cast-adds-four-and-loses-one-more|title='Saturday Night Live' Cast Adds Four and Loses One More - NYTimes.com|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 7, 2010|accessdate=February 24, 2011}} In August 2010, she co-wrote and voiced ''[[Marcel the Shell with Shoes On]]'', which garnered viral success. This led to ''Marcel the Shell with Shoes on, Two''.{{Cite news|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/08/17/jenny-slatess-marcel-the-shell-with-shoes-on-is-fantastic/|title=Jenny Slates's 'Marcel the Shell with Shoes On' is fantastic|last=Lyons|first=Margaret|date=August 17, 2010|work=PopWatch|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=August 18, 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/popcandy/post/2010/08/exclusive-snl-star-jenny-slate-chats-about-marcel-the-shell/1|title=Exclusive: 'SNL' star Jenny Slate chats about 'Marcel the Shell'|last=Matheson|first=Whitney|date=August 29, 2010|work=Pop Candy|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=August 30, 2010}} Slate also wrote a "Marcel"-themed children's book that was released on November 1, 2011.{{cite web|last=Swerdloff |first=Alexis |url=http://www.papermag.com/arts_and_style/2010/11/jenny-slate-emerges-from-her-shellas-a-shell.php |title=Jenny Slate Emerges From Her Shell ... As A Shell |publisher=Papermag.com |date=November 3, 2010 |accessdate=February 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101106165211/http://www.papermag.com/arts_and_style/2010/11/jenny-slate-emerges-from-her-shellas-a-shell.php |archivedate=November 6, 2010 |df= }} Her first major film role was as Zoe in ''[[Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked]]''; more films followed in 2012, including the voice of Ted's mother in ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]''. Her first appearance in ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' was in the 2013 episode "Bailout", in which she portrayed Mona-Lisa Saperstein. Following her success on the NBC show, Slate released and starred in a 12 episode mini-series on YouTube called ''Catherine'', celebrating late 1980' and early 1990s soap opera aesthetics.{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2940332/|title=Catherine|date=May 19, 2013|accessdate=June 23, 2016}} On July 23, 2013, she appeared in ''[[Drunk History]]'' retelling the history of how [[Coca-Cola]] was made. In 2014, Slate starred in the comedy-drama film ''[[Obvious Child]]'', which follows the life of a young stand up comic as she grapples with an unplanned pregnancy and eventual abortion.{{cite web|last1=Pickett|first1=Leah|title=Performance of the Year: Jenny Slate|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2014/12/performance-of-the-year-2014/|website=Consequence of Sound}} Slate went on to win the [[Critics' Choice Movie Awards|Critics Choice Award]] for Best Actress in a Comedy,{{cite web|last1=Cappadona|first1=Bryanna|title=Jenny Slate Wins Big at the Critics' Choice Awards|url=http://www.bostonmagazine.com/arts-entertainment/blog/2015/01/16/jenny-slate-critics-choice-awards-2015/|website=Boston Magazine}} Best Breakout Performance at the Newport Beach Film Festival, the Virtuosos Award at the Santa Barbara Film Festival, and Best Comedic Actress at the Women Film Circle Awards for her performance in the film. Slate co-starred with [[Judy Greer]] and [[Nat Faxon]] in the first season of the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] series ''[[Married (TV series)|Married]]''.{{cite web |url=http://splitsider.com/2014/01/fx-orders-series-starring-nat-faxon-judy-greer-brett-gelman-and-jenny-slate-coming-in-july/ |title=FX Orders Series Starring Nat Faxon, Judy Greer, Brett Gelman, and Jenny Slate; Coming in July |publisher=Splitsider |date=January 24, 2014}} She left the series as a series regular in season two, but still appeared in a few episodes. [[Sarah Burns]] took her place in the series. Slate appeared as Liz B. in the recurring "PubLIZity" sketches in ''[[Kroll Show]]'', as well as many other recurring and one-off characters, performing in some capacity in almost every episode until the series ended in 2015. In 2016, Slate voiced Dawn Bellwether in the [[Disney]] animated comedy-adventure film ''[[Zootopia]]'' and Gidget in the animated feature ''[[The Secret Life of Pets]]''. Slate and her father co-wrote a book about their time living in Slate's childhood home in Milton, Massachusetts, titled ''About the House,'' which was published in December 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonmagazine.com/property/blog/2016/11/03/jenny-slate-milton-house/|title=Jenny Slate and Her Father Wrote a Book About Their House in Milton|date=November 3, 2016|access-date=February 15, 2017|author=Madeline Bilis|periodical=[[Boston Magazine]]}} In 2017, Slate starred in the film ''[[Gifted (film)|Gifted]]'' as Bonnie Stevenson, the teacher of a 7-year-old mathematical genius. ==Personal life== She lived in [[Cobble Hill, Brooklyn]], before moving with her former husband to Los Angeles in the early 2010s.{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/laugh-track-jenny-slates-winding-road-from-snl-to-obvious-child-20140602|title=How Jenny Slate Went from an 'SNL' Blunder to 'Obvious ChildSuccess|last=Battan|first=Carrie|date=June 2, 2014|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|quote=Slate decamped for Los Angeles a couple of years ago with her now-husband, director Dean Fleischer-Camp.|accessdate=June 4, 2014|archivedate=May 6, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506044721/http://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/laugh-track-jenny-slates-winding-road-from-snl-to-obvious-child-20140602|deadurl=no}} In September 2012, Slate married filmmaker Dean Fleischer-Camp,{{cite news |last=Killoran |first=Ellen |url= http://www.thelmagazine.com/gyrobase/the-rise-and-fall-and-rise-of-jenny-slate/Content?oid=2104645&storyPage=1|title=The Rise and Fall and Rise of Jenny Slate |work=[[L Magazine]] |date=May 25, 2011 |accessdate=June 19, 2011}} with whom she collaborated on the ''Marcel the Shell with Shoes On'' books and short films. The pair announced their separation in May 2016. Slate dated actor [[Chris Evans (actor)|Chris Evans]] for nine months until they broke up in early 2017{{Cite news|url=https://www.eonline.com/news/827684/chris-evans-and-jenny-slate-break-up-after-9-months-of-dating|title=Chris Evans and Jenny Slate Break Up|work=E! Online|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}. They got back together in the fall of 2017, but Evans confirmed in March 2018 that they had separated once more.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/22/theater/chris-evans-lobby-hero-captain-america.html|title=Chris Evans, a.k.a. Captain America, Comes Back Down to Earth|date=2018-03-22|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Title ! scope="col" | Role ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2010 | ''[[Marcel the Shell with Shoes On]]'' | Marcel | Short film
Also writer |- | 2011 | ''[[Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked]]'' | Zoe | |- | rowspan="2"|2012 | ''[[This Means War (film)|This Means War]]'' | Emily | |- | ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]'' | Mrs. Wiggins (voice) | |- | 2013 | ''Bitch'' | Molly Horner | Short film |- | rowspan="2"|2014 | ''[[Obvious Child]]'' | Donna Stern | [[Newport Beach Film Festival|Newport Beach Film Festival Award for Breakout Actress]]
[[Santa Barbara International Film Festival|Santa Barbara International Film Festival Award for Virtuoso Award]]
[[Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Actress in a Comedy]]
[[Women Film Critics Circle]] Award for Best Comedic Actress
Nominated—[[Independent Spirit Award for Best Female Lead]]
Nominated—[[Chicago Film Critics Association|Chicago Film Critics Association Award for Most Promising Performer]]
Nominated—[[Gotham Independent Film Awards 2014|Gotham Award for Breakthrough Actor]]
Nominated—[[Seattle International Film Festival|Seattle International Film Festival Award for Best Actress]]
Nominated—Phoenix Film Critics Society Award for Breakthrough Performance on Camera
Nominated—Women Film Critics Circle Award for Best Screen Couple |- | ''[[The Longest Week]]'' | Jocelyn | |- | 2015 | ''[[Digging for Fire]]'' | Yoga Couple | |- | rowspan="5"|2016 | ''[[Joshy (film)|Joshy]]'' | Jodi | |- | ''[[Zootopia]]'' | Dawn Bellwether (voice) | |- | ''[[My Blind Brother]]'' | Rose | |- | ''[[The Secret Life of Pets]]'' | Gidget (voice) | |- | ''[[Brain on Fire (film)|Brain on Fire]]'' | Margo | |- | rowspan="6"|2017 | ''[[Landline (film)|Landline]]'' | Dana Jacobs | |- | ''[[The Polka King]]'' | Marla Lewan | |- | ''[[The Lego Batman Movie]]'' | [[Harley Quinn|Harleen Quinzel / Harley Quinn]] (voice) | |- | ''[[Gifted (film)|Gifted]]'' | Bonnie | |- | ''[[Aardvark (film)|Aardvark]]'' | Emily Milburton | |- | ''[[Despicable Me 3]]'' | Valerie Da Vinci (voice) | |- | rowspan="2"|2018 | ''[[Hotel Artemis]]'' | Morgan | |- | ''[[Venom (2018 film)|Venom]]'' | Dr. Dora Skirth | ''Post-production'' |- | rowspan="2"|2019 | ''[[The Ark and the Aardvark]]'' | Mitzi (voice) | ''In production'' |- |''[[The Secret Life of Pets 2]]'' | Gidget (voice) | ''In production'' |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Title ! scope="col" | Role ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2005 | ''[[Starved]]'' | Member of Belt Tighteners | Uncredited
Episode: "The Breatharians" |- | 2008 | ''[[The Whitest Kids U' Know]]'' | Trevor's Date | Episode #2.1 |- | 2009 | ''[[Important Things with Demetri Martin]]'' | Bride | Episode: "Chairs" |- | 2009 | ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' | Jenny the Page | 8 episodes |- | 2009 | ''[[Brothers (2009 TV series)|Brothers]]'' | Annette | 2 episodes |- | 2009–10 | ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' | Various | 22 episodes |- | 2009 | ''[[Bored to Death]]'' | Stella | 5 episodes |- | 2011 | ''[[Ugly Americans (TV series)|Ugly Americans]]'' | Jaclyn (voice) | Episode: "Lily and the Beast" |- | 2012 | ''[[Raising Hope]]'' | Joan | Episode: "Throw Maw Maw from the House" |- | 2012–16 | ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'' | Tally Schifrin | 2 episodes |- | 2012–present | ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'' | Tammy Larsen (voice) | 30 episodes |- | 2013 | ''[[Hello Ladies]]'' | Amelia Gordon | 4 episodes |- | 2013 | ''[[Super Fun Night]]'' | Helen-Alice | Unaired CBS pilot |- | 2013–15 | ''[[Kroll Show]]'' | Liz / Denise / Various | 7 episodes |- | 2013–15 | ''[[House of Lies]]'' | Sarah Guggenheim | 9 episodes |- | 2013–15 | ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' | Mona-Lisa Saperstein | 8 episodes |- | 2013–16 | ''[[Drunk History]]'' | Herself | 3 episodes |- | 2014 | ''[[Brooklyn Nine-Nine]]'' | Bianca | Episode: "[[Undercover (Brooklyn Nine-Nine)|Undercover]]" |- | 2014 | ''[[The Getaway (TV series)|The Getaway]]'' | Herself | Episode: "Jenny Slate In Barcelona" |- | 2014–15 | ''[[Married (TV series)|Married]]'' | Jess | 14 episodes |- | 2015–present | ''[[Star vs. the Forces of Evil]]'' | Pony Head (voice) | 18 episodes |- | 2016–18 | ''[[Adventure Time]]'' | Huntress Wizard (voice) | 4 episodes |- | 2016 | ''[[Animals.]]'' | Snake (voice) | Episode: "Squirrels. Part I." |- | 2016–17 | ''[[Lady Dynamite]]'' | Karen Grisham (life coach) | 4 episodes |- | 2017 | ''[[Comrade Detective]]'' | Jane (voice) | 6 episodes |- | 2017–present | ''[[Big Mouth (TV series)|Big Mouth]]'' | Missy (voice) | 10 episodes |- | 2018–present | ''[[Muppet Babies (2018 TV series)|Muppet Babies]]'' | Miss Nanny (voice) | Main role{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2018/02/06/muppet-babies-reboot-jenny-slate-nanny-full-cast-list/|title=Muppet Babies Reboot: Jenny Slate to Voice the Iconic, Faceless 'Miss Nanny'|first=Andy|last=Swift|date=February 6, 2018|work=[[TV Line]]|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Jenny Slate}} * {{IMDb name|2809577}} * {{vimeo|gabeandjenny|Gabe and Jenny}} {{Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Actress in a Comedy}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Slate, Jenny}} [[Category:1982 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:21st-century American actresses]] [[Category:21st-century American women writers]] [[Category:American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:American female singers]] [[Category:American children's writers]] [[Category:American impressionists (entertainers)]] [[Category:American voice actresses]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:American women comedians]] [[Category:American feminist writers]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Jewish American actresses]] [[Category:Jewish feminists]] [[Category:Jewish American comedians]] [[Category:Milton Academy alumni]] [[Category:American women children's writers]] [[Category:Actresses from Massachusetts]] [[Category:People from Milton, Massachusetts]] [[Category:American sketch comedians]] [[Category:Comedians from Massachusetts]] [[Category:Upright Citizens Brigade Theater performers]]
